div1.head: Jim to Mlle. Marcelle Guerin Feb. 5th 1916
div1.p: Comme vous voyez I am still here. Was all ready to start an hour or so ago when it started in to rain again. A large crowd had gathered and I was sorry to disappoint them. I walked into town with a rather chic person who said her husband wouldn’t mind her walking with an aviator. Seems an aviator is some class in these parts. I apologized for my get up as I hadn’t figured on being in a town and only had on my leathers and a crummy looking blue coat with a pass — montagne. Instead of saying that was all right she agreed that I looked fierce and not at all like other aviators she had seen, which was amusing. We took her boy in and got him some cakes and then I came to this cafe to write you a note. I’ll surely get away to morrow and if lucky I’ll be breveted a day after.

Marcelle, you’re funny some
times. About Paul’s remark and the Russian Ballet. Can’t you jolly along as the rest of us do — as Paul did. Quite harmless I assure you, and no reason to be serious and shocked. My only diversion here is reading your last letter. I received it just before I started and took it with me.

Its terrible to think of you being exposed to the Zeffelin attacks. You are sure to go into the cave aren’t you when they come? You’ll be all right there and there’s no use exposing yourself for no end.

I shall see you before I go to the front. Of that you may be sure. Maybe I’ll go to Paris after my brevet but don’t know as we get but four days permission and its not worth while. If I had had luck I would have been breveted to day as I’ve finished all my other voyages. Its just a month since I started training and I’ve had but 14 or 15 hours of flight in all. Best to your mother and father and yourself, of course.
